incomeBrackets.label: Working Poor
incomeBrackets.description: It's a grind. Every dollar is stretched. Instant noodles are practically a currency.

incomeBrackets.label: Low Income
incomeBrackets.description: Budgeting is an art form. A night out for pizza is a rare, celebrated event.

incomeBrackets.label: Lower Middle Class
incomeBrackets.description: Essentials are covered, maybe a concert ticket. Saving is tough but not impossible.

incomeBrackets.label: Middle Class
incomeBrackets.description: Comfortable, but mindful of spending. Starting to build that nest egg and a 401k.

incomeBrackets.label: Upper Middle Class
incomeBrackets.description: Life's pretty good! More treats, less stress. Investments are growing.

incomeBrackets.label: Affluent
incomeBrackets.description: Enjoying the finer things. Weekend getaways and nice dinners are regular occurrences.

incomeBrackets.label: High Income
incomeBrackets.description: Luxury choices become normal. Shopping at upscale department stores without wincing!

incomeBrackets.label: Wealthy
incomeBrackets.description: Premium experiences are the standard. Your financial advisor is a good friend.

incomeBrackets.label: Very Wealthy
incomeBrackets.description: Elite living. 'Fly commercial or private?' is a genuine dilemma.

incomeBrackets.label: Ultra High Net Worth
incomeBrackets.description: Exclusive access. Your hobbies sound like movie plots.

incomeBrackets.label: Millionaire
incomeBrackets.description: Congrats, you made it! Now, the fun part: smart allocation and enjoying the fruits.

incomeBrackets.label: Multi-Millionaire
incomeBrackets.description: Private jet for a quick European city break? Sure, why not.

incomeBrackets.label: Ultra Wealthy
incomeBrackets.description: The world is your playground. You might own the company that makes the playground equipment.

incomeBrackets.label: Ultra Elite
incomeBrackets.description: Your biggest worry? Which continent for the summer. Philanthropy becomes a significant focus.

incomeBrackets.label: Billionaire Class
incomeBrackets.description: Price tags are suggestions. Next stop: influencing global change (or funding space exploration).

items.title: Home Cook Hero (by necessity!)
items.desc: Pasta, rice, beans are staples. Supermarket generic brands are gold. A rare splurge: a $5 pizza from Little Caesars or Domino's, or a local takeaway.
items.financialNote: Food budget is extremely tight.

items.title: Grocery Ninja
items.desc: $150-200/month (or local equivalent). Couponing isn't just a hobby, it's a survival skill. Eating out is a distant dream.
items.financialNote: Focus on maximizing every dollar for essentials.

items.title: Casual Eats & Local Diners
items.desc: Hitting up a local diner or a casual chain like Applebee's, Chili's (North America), or Nando's (UK/International) a few times a month. You know the happy hour specials.
items.financialNote: Dining out is a budgeted treat.

items.title: Smart Grocery Runs
items.desc: $400/month (or local equivalent) at large supermarket chains (e.g., Kroger, Tesco, Carrefour, Woolworths). Maybe some organic produce if it's on sale.
items.financialNote: Groceries are a significant, planned expense.

items.title: Foodie Adventures
items.desc: Weekly dinners at popular local restaurants or trendy food halls. Craft beers at a local microbrewery. Exploring different cuisines.

items.title: Premium Pantry Stocking
items.desc: $600+/month (or local equivalent). Regular trips to Whole Foods Market, Marks & Spencer Foodhall, Waitrose, or local organic markets. You invest in the good olive oil and artisanal bread.

items.title: Fine Dining Connoisseur
items.desc: Regular reservations at Michelin-starred or equivalent top-rated local restaurants (e.g., those listed in World's 50 Best). Wine pairings are non-negotiable.

items.title: Gourmet Home Experience
items.desc: $1500+/month on food & wine. Shopping at specialty food stores (e.g., Eataly, Dean & DeLuca style gourmet shops, local fromageries and butchers). Perhaps a high-end La Cornue, Wolf, or Gaggenau range.

items.title: Private Chef & Exclusive Tables
items.desc: Personal chef for special occasions or weekly meal prep. Access to private dining rooms at globally renowned establishments like Noma (Copenhagen), The French Laundry (Yountville), Osteria Francescana (Modena).

items.title: Curated Wine Cellar
items.desc: Investing in rare and fine wines (e.g., Bordeaux First Growths, Grand Cru Burgundy, cult Napa Cabernets like Screaming Eagle), possibly with a consultant from Sotheby's or Christie's. Trips to Napa, Tuscany, or Bordeaux for 'research' and vineyard tours.

items.title: Roommate Shuffle
items.desc: Renting a room in an older building in a less central part of town, or a shared flat. Fingers crossed for compatible roommates!
items.financialNote: Rent consumes a large portion of income.

items.title: Furniture Finds
items.desc: Mostly thrift store treasures, Facebook Marketplace finds, or generous hand-me-downs. You're a DIY wizard with YouTube tutorials.
items.financialNote: Furnishing relies on resourcefulness, not budget.

items.title: Your Own Cozy Corner
items.desc: Studio or 1BR apartment in a decent, accessible neighborhood. Small, but all yours!
items.financialNote: Rent is a primary, manageable expense.

items.title: IKEA & Target Style
items.desc: Assembling flat-pack furniture is a rite of passage. That IKEA KALLAX shelf or BILLY bookcase is a global icon for a reason. Maybe some affordable pieces from Target, Kmart, or Wayfair.

items.title: Homeownership Horizons
items.desc: Eyeing a modest starter home, apartment, or townhome in a family-friendly suburb or an up-and-coming city neighborhood.
items.financialNote: Managing mortgage, property taxes, and HOA fees.

items.title: Mid-Range Furniture Upgrade
items.desc: Upgrading furniture. Maybe a brand-new couch from a mid-range store like West Elm, CB2, Pottery Barn, John Lewis, or Habitat. Investing in better quality mattresses and linens.

items.title: Luxury Living
items.desc: A spacious, well-appointed home in a desirable neighborhood, or a luxury condo/apartment with amenities (gym, pool, concierge) in the city center. Heated bathroom floors, smart home features.
items.financialNote: Property is a significant asset.

items.title: Designer Touches & Renovations
items.desc: Working with an interior designer. Custom cabinetry from brands like Poggenpohl, Smallbone, or Boffi. Investing in original art. Dream kitchen with Sub-Zero, Wolf, or Miele appliances.

items.title: Multiple Luxury Properties
items.desc: Primary residence in an exclusive enclave. A ski chalet, a beach house, perhaps a country estate or a city pied-Ã -terre. These properties are often in different countries.
items.financialNote: Managing a portfolio of international properties.

items.title: Custom Architecture & Staff
items.desc: Commissioning a renowned architect for a bespoke home. Full-time household staff including a house manager, private chef, nannies, housekeepers, and security detail.

items.title: Public Transit Pro
items.desc: You've mastered the local bus, subway/tram, or train system. Walking and a trusty (if rusty) bike are your companions.
items.financialNote: Transportation costs are minimized.

items.title: The 'Character' Car
items.desc: If you own a car, it's an older, high-mileage model. Gas/petrol, insurance, and unexpected repairs are major budget concerns.
items.financialNote: Car ownership is a significant, unpredictable expense.

items.title: Reliable Used Wheels
items.desc: A dependable used Honda Civic, Toyota Corolla, VW Golf/Polo. Focus on fuel efficiency and reliability.
items.financialNote: Car payments or savings are budgeted.

items.title: Ride-Share Regular
items.desc: Using Uber/Lyft/Bolt/Grab for nights out, airport runs, or after a few drinks.

items.title: That New(ish) Car Scent
items.desc: A new, practical car like a Subaru Outback/Forester, Honda CR-V, Toyota RAV4, Mazda CX-5, VW Tiguan, or Nissan Qashqai. Maybe an entry-level EV.
items.financialNote: Managing a car loan effectively.

items.title: Worry-Free Maintenance
items.desc: Regular dealer services, comprehensive insurance. That check engine light causes less panic. Perhaps an extended warranty.

items.title: Luxury Commuting
items.desc: Driving a Tesla Model Y/S/3 Performance, BMW X5/5 Series, Audi Q7/A6, Mercedes-Benz GLE/E-Class, Range Rover Sport, or a Porsche Macan/Cayenne.
items.financialNote: Depreciation is factored into net worth.

items.title: The Two-Car (or more) Household
items.desc: A practical luxury daily driver plus a 'fun' weekend car â perhaps a Porsche Boxster/Cayman, a Ford Mustang GT, or a classic sports car.

items.title: Exotic Car Collection
items.desc: Ferraris, Lamborghinis, McLarens. Maybe a bespoke Rolls-Royce or Bentley. Climate-controlled garage is a must.
items.financialNote: Cars may be passion assets or collectibles.

items.title: Private Driver / Chauffeur
items.desc: Full-time chauffeur for daily transport in a luxury sedan or SUV. Never worry about parking or traffic again.

items.title: Staycation Pro
items.desc: Exploring local parks, free museum days, and nearby nature trails. Camping in state/national parks or local campsites is the annual big adventure.
items.financialNote: Travel budget is virtually non-existent.

items.title: Roadtrip Co-Pilot
items.desc: Chipping in for gas/petrol if a friend with a car is heading to a nearby city, beach, or natural attraction. You bring the snacks and make the playlist!

items.title: Budget Domestic Explorer
items.desc: Annual flight on a budget airline like Spirit, Ryanair, EasyJet, or Southwest. Weekend trips to nearby cities. Staying in budget hotels or well-rated hostels.
items.financialNote: Travel is carefully budgeted and saved for.

items.title: Regional Escapes
items.desc: Driving to nearby attractions, national parks, or smaller cities for a weekend. Camping is still a favorite and cost-effective option, maybe upgrading to a cabin rental.

items.title: International Adventures Begin
items.desc: First trips to popular international destinations like Mexico, Canada, or a well-planned week in a major European city, likely staying in Airbnbs, boutique hotels, or mid-range hotels.
items.financialNote: Travel is a regular, planned expense.

items.title: Comfortable Domestic Travel
items.desc: Flying major airlines, staying in reputable mid-tier hotels like Hilton, Marriott. Maybe a ski trip, a beach vacation, or exploring national parks in more comfort.

items.title: Business Class & Luxury Resorts
items.desc: Flying business class internationally (e.g., Emirates, Singapore Airlines). Staying at 5-star resorts and hotels (e.g., Four Seasons, St. Regis, Aman). Maybe a luxury cruise line.

items.title: Adventure & Experiential Travel
items.desc: Safaris in Africa (e.g. Singita, &Beyond lodges), exploring Patagonia, cultural immersion in Japan, diving in Galapagos. Unique, curated experiences are prioritized.

items.title: First Class & Private Aviation
items.desc: Flying first class suites (e.g., Etihad The Residence). Fractional ownership of a private jet (NetJets, Flexjet) or chartering (e.g. Gulfstream G650).

items.title: World-Circling Itineraries & Unique Stays
items.desc: Extended trips to multiple continents, perhaps on a private jet world tour. Owning multiple vacation homes. Private yacht charters (Lurssen, Feadship).

items.title: Free Fun Seeker
items.desc: Public library, free local concerts, hiking. Streaming via 'borrowed' accounts or ad-supported tiers (Spotify Free, YouTube).
items.financialNote: Entertainment limited to free options.

items.title: DIY Entertainment
items.desc: Drawing, writing, learning from YouTube. Board games with friends. Imagination is key.

items.title: Local Gigs & Movies
items.desc: Catching a local band, movies at matinee prices. A couple of basic streaming services (Netflix basic).
items.financialNote: Small, planned entertainment expenses.

items.title: Social Outings
items.desc: Meeting friends for happy hour. Bowling, local amateur sports, trivia nights.

items.title: Major Concerts & Sporting Events
items.desc: Tickets to see major artists (Taylor Swift, Coldplay) or pro sports. Maybe a local ski pass.

items.title: Quality Home Entertainment
items.desc: Good 4K TV (LG OLED), sound system (Sonos), new gaming console (PS5/Xbox). Multiple streaming subscriptions (Netflix Premium, HBO Max).

items.title: VIP & Season Tickets
items.desc: VIP packages for concerts/festivals (Coachella). Season tickets (club level) for pro sports. Private social or sports club memberships.

items.title: High-End Hobbies & Collections
items.desc: Collecting art (Art Basel), fine wines, vintage guitars (Gibson '59 Les Paul). Golf memberships at exclusive clubs. Attending Monaco Grand Prix or Wimbledon.

items.title: Courtside & Backstage Access
items.desc: Courtside seats at NBA games, front row at Paris Fashion Week (Chanel). Backstage passes. Attending Oscars, Cannes Film Festival, Met Gala.

items.title: Funding the Arts / Owning a Team
items.desc: Significant patron of major museums (MoMA, Tate), opera (Metropolitan Opera). Investing in Broadway or film. Part-ownership of a pro sports franchise.

items.title: Public Library University
items.desc: Local library, free online courses (Coursera audit, Khan Academy). YouTube tutorials.
items.financialNote: Education via free resources.

items.title: Self-Taught & Resourceful
items.desc: Learning via podcasts, documentaries, internet research. Mentorship if available. Skill-swapping.

items.title: Community College / In-State Public University
items.desc: Affordable local degrees/certificates or state university with loans/part-time work.
items.financialNote: Managing student loan debt.

items.title: Trade Schools & Certifications
items.desc: Practical skills via vocational programs, apprenticeships, online certs (Google Career Certificates, CompTIA).

items.title: Choice of Public or Private University
items.desc: Well-regarded private or flagship state university with savings/scholarships/manageable loans. MBA from state school or online (UIUC, Indiana Kelley).
items.financialNote: Paying down student loans while investing.

items.title: Continuing Education & Workshops
items.desc: Investing in professional development courses, industry conferences (CES, Web Summit), specialized workshops. LinkedIn Learning, MasterClass.

items.title: Elite Universities & Grad School
items.desc: Attending Ivy League or top-tier global universities (Stanford, MIT, Oxbridge, INSEAD for MBA) for undergrad/grad.
items.financialNote: Education costs are manageable.

items.title: Private Tutors & Specialized Coaching
items.desc: Hiring tutors for children (SAT/ACT prep via Crimson Education), executive coaching (BetterUp), language immersion abroad, specialized skill retreats (Le Cordon Bleu for enthusiasts).

items.title: Global Education & Bespoke Learning for Family
items.desc: Children attend elite international boarding schools (Le Rosey, Eton, Phillips Exeter). Custom educational programs, 'world-schooling' with private tutors.

items.title: University Donations & Endowments
items.desc: Significant philanthropic contributions to alma mater/prestigious institutions (named buildings/professorships). Funding research. Pursuing personal intellectual interests (Aspen Ideas Festival, TED).

items.title: The Ultimate DIY-er
items.desc: Cutting own hair, cleaning own home, DIY repairs. Mending clothes.
items.financialNote: Services self-performed to save money.

items.title: Community Support System
items.desc: Relying on friends/family for moves, childcare, pet-sitting. Bartering skills. Utilizing free community services.

items.title: Basic Maintenance Services
items.desc: Budget haircuts (Great Clips). Occasional TaskRabbit for heavy lifting or basic handyman task.
items.financialNote: Limited use of paid services.

items.title: Occasional House Cleaner or Meal Kit
items.desc: House cleaning as a rare treat. Trying a meal kit delivery service (HelloFresh, Blue Apron) for convenience.

items.title: Regular Pampering & Assistance
items.desc: Monthly mid-range salon haircuts (Toni&Guy). Bi-weekly house cleaning. Lawn care. Regular food delivery (DoorDash). Occasional dog walker.

items.title: Personal Trainer & Wellness Subscriptions
items.desc: Nicer gym membership (Equinox, Virgin Active), boutique fitness (F45, Barry's). ClassPass. Regular massages. Wellness apps (Headspace).

items.title: Concierge Lifestyle Services
items.desc: Personal assistant (part/full-time, virtual via Time etc). Premium spa treatments (Peninsula Spa). Personal shopper/stylist (Nordstrom, Selfridges).

items.title: Household Support Staff
items.desc: Full/part-time nanny. Regular professional landscaping, pool maintenance. Dog walker, mobile pet groomer. Private chef for some meals. Tailor.

items.title: Full Estate Management & Bespoke Staff
items.desc: Butler, private chef (Michelin-experienced), full-time skilled housekeeping, groundskeepers, personal security detail (close protection). Estate manager/chief of staff.

items.title: Bespoke Global Concierge
items.desc: Access to high-end concierge services (Quintessentially, Ten Lifestyle Group, Knightsbridge Circle) for any request: superyacht charters, sourcing rare HermÃ¨s/Patek Philippe, exclusive party planning.

items.title: Survival Mode & Basic Banking
items.desc: Focus on meeting immediate needs. May use check-cashing services or rely on basic bank accounts with minimal fees. Debt is often high-interest (payday loans, credit cards for essentials). Savings are non-existent or for very short-term emergencies. No investments.

items.title: Community Assistance
items.desc: May rely on community financial literacy programs, credit counseling from non-profits, or government assistance programs if available and eligible. Financial stability is precarious.

items.title: Building Foundations
items.desc: Establishing an emergency fund (3-6 months expenses) is a key goal. Starting to contribute to employer-sponsored retirement plans (401k, pension) to get any employer match, or opening a Roth IRA. Initial investments in simple, low-cost target-date funds or broad market index funds (e.g., S&P 500 - VOO, Total Stock Market - VTI).

items.title: Debt Management & Budgeting
items.desc: Actively working to pay down high-interest debt (credit cards, personal loans). Utilizing budgeting apps (e.g., YNAB, Mint) and focusing on financial education regarding compound interest and long-term planning.

items.title: Wealth Accumulation Phase
items.desc: Aiming to max out tax-advantaged retirement accounts (401k, IRA, HSA). Building a diversified portfolio in taxable brokerage accounts with low-cost index funds covering US large/small cap, international stocks, and possibly some bonds. Asset allocation becomes a conscious decision.

items.title: Robo-Advisors & Goal-Based Savings
items.desc: May use robo-advisors (e.g., Betterment, Wealthfront) for automated investment management and tax-loss harvesting. Saving for specific goals like a house down payment, children's education (529 plans). Understanding of investment fees and tax implications grows.

items.title: Comprehensive Financial Planning
items.desc: Portfolio likely exceeds $500K. Often engage a fee-only financial advisor or planner for holistic advice. Focus on tax optimization: strategic asset location, tax-loss harvesting, charitable giving strategies. May invest in individual stocks or more specialized ETFs/mutual funds.

items.title: Exploring Alternative Investments
items.desc: Considering direct real estate investments (rental properties), REITs, or contributing to private real estate syndications. Early-stage estate planning (wills, basic trusts). Insurance review (life, disability, umbrella).

items.title: Sophisticated Wealth Management
items.desc: Portfolio typically $1.5M-$5M+. Managing substantial assets requires vigilance. May diversify into hedge funds, private equity, or venture capital through platforms or direct investment. Advanced tax planning, including strategies for concentrated stock positions or business ownership.

items.title: Family Office & Legacy Planning
items.desc: For portfolios $5M+, often involves a private wealth manager, multi-family office, or establishing a single-family office. Focus on intergenerational wealth transfer, complex trust structures (GRATs, QPRTs, ILITs), philanthropic strategies (donor-advised funds, private foundations), and asset protection. Managing international assets and tax laws if applicable.
